<gene_function>
The *urtD* gene encodes the ATP-binding component of the ABC-type urea transporter complex (UrtABCDE) in cyanobacteria. This transporter facilitates high-affinity urea uptake at concentrations below 1 μM, enabling nitrogen assimilation from urea sources[1][3][4]. The *urtABCDE* operon is transcriptionally regulated by the global nitrogen regulator NtcA and post-translationally controlled by the P<sub>II</sub> signal transduction protein, linking urea uptake to cellular nitrogen status[3][4]. In *Synechocystis* and *Anabaena* sp. PCC 7120, UrtD provides energy for urea import through ATP hydrolysis[1][4].

<physiological_impact>
UrtD is essential for nitrogen acquisition under urea-replete conditions. Inactivation of the urea transporter impairs growth when urea is the sole nitrogen source, disrupting cellular nitrogen homeostasis[1][4]. This directly affects biomass production and photosynthetic efficiency, as nitrogen is critical for chlorophyll synthesis and carbon fixation[1][5]. Cyanobacteria lacking functional UrtD exhibit reduced fitness in nitrogen-fluctuating environments[3].

</physiological_impact>

This allows rapid adjustment of urea uptake to changing nitrogen availability. No direct role in heat/salt stress is documented.

</stress_response>
